channel.title: RLIG
channel.description: Blog of the Record Linkage Interest Group

item.title: Linkage Seminar Series - Friday April 1st
item.dc:creator: RLIG
item.description: Roee Gutman will present work that view record linkage as a missing data problem and he will describe Bayesian procedures that utilize data features that are frequently encountered in public health applications.

item.title: BLS Statistical Seminar on Monday, March 28th
item.dc:creator: RLIG
item.description: Data Analysis after Record Linkage: sources of error, consequences, and possible solutions, Dr. Martin Slawski, Department of Statistics, Volgenau School of Engineering, George Mason University

item.title: deepparse
item.dc:creator: Marouane Yassine
David Beauchemin
item.description: Deepparse: a state-of-the-art Python library for parsing multinational street addresses using deep learning.

item.title: Linkage Seminar Series - Thursday February 24
item.dc:creator: RLIG
item.description: For February’s Linkage Seminar, Amy O’Hara will be joined by Thais Menezes, a PhD student at SFI Centre for Research Training in Foundations of Data Science, University College Dublin. Thais’ work incorporates the household structure in recording linkage matching in the Ireland census database to make the process of matching individuals easier and more accurate.

item.title: Record Linkage at the Duke GPSG Community Pantry
item.dc:creator: Olivier Binette
item.description: The Duke Graduate and Professional Student Government (GPSG) Community Pantry is a student-operated food pantry serving the student community at Duke University. In this post, I describe the record linkage system used at the Pantry to identify individual customers and obtain their order history. This is done using a Python module for deterministic record linkage and model evaluation techniques which I describe in detail.

item.title: Welcome!
item.dc:creator: Olivier Binette
item.description: Welcome to the blog of ASA's Record Linkage Interest Group.
